aave.name: Metric 1: Onchain Control
aave.about: This metric evaluates whether economically material outcomes are mediated through tokenholder governance, or whether admins, multisigs, security councils, or other privileged roles retain onchain powers that can change the rules or selectively restrict use and exit.
aave.summary: AAVE, stkAAVE and aAAVE holders control the protocol through onchain governance with Timelock execution. The token has fixed 16M supply with no mint function. Delegated steward roles exist but are elected and revocable by governance.

criteria.name: On-chain Governance Workflow
criteria.about: Evaluates whether an onchain process exists that grants tokenholders ultimate authority over protocol decisions.
criteria.notes: AAVE, stkAAVE and aAAVE holders vote onchain with execution through Timelock.

criteria.name: Role Accountability
criteria.about: Determines whether all privileged or value-impacting roles are governed, revocable, and accountable to tokenholders.
criteria.notes:
**Governance Emergency Guardian** is a 5/9 multisig elected by community to protect the protocol from governance takeover attacks by vetoing onchain payloads.

**Members:** Seb (Zapper), Mounir (Paraswap), Gavi Galloway (Standard Crypto), Nenad (Defi Saver), Fernando (Balancer), Roger (Chainlink community), Mariano Conti (DeFi OG), Marin (Lido), Certora (security service provider).

criteria.name: Protocol Upgrade Authority
criteria.about: Determines whether core protocol logic can be upgraded and whether such upgrades are controlled by tokenholders.
criteria.notes:
Holders control implementation upgrades for all v3 market deployments.

**Upgrade path:** Pool (upgradeable proxy) → Admin is PoolAddressProvider → onlyOwner is Executor → owner is PayloadsController → controlled by Governance.

For PayloadsController to call Executor, MESSAGE_ORIGINATOR must equal Governance for a proposal to execute.

criteria.name: Token Upgrade Authority
criteria.about: Assesses whether token behavior can be modified and, if so, whether such changes are controlled by tokenholder governance.
criteria.notes:
Contract is a variant of the upgradeable ERC-1967 Transparent proxy, owned by ProxyAdmin, which is controlled by token holders.

**Ownership chain:** AAVE (Proxy) → ProxyAdmin → Executor → PayloadsController → Token Holders

criteria.name: Supply Control
criteria.about: Evaluates whether token supply changes are programmatic or subject exclusively to tokenholder-approved governance processes.
criteria.notes: Fixed 16m AAVE token supply. No mint() function or inflation pathway in the bytecode.

urls.name: The only AAVE token minting transactions ever, amounting to 16m AAVE tokens

criteria.name: Privileged Access Gating
criteria.about: Assesses whether any bounded actor set can block or selectively restrict economically meaningful protocol actions or exit paths, versus access that is permissionless and symmetric for similarly situated users.
criteria.notes:
Roles can be broadly classified into **Core Protocol Roles** and **Delegated Steward Roles**. AAVE holders elect and revoke all these roles with their standard governance procedure.

**Core Protocol Roles:** EMERGENCY_ADMIN, RISK_ADMIN, POOL_ADMIN, ASSET_LISTING_ADMIN. These live in ACLManager, owned by ACLAdmin (verifiable in PoolAddressesProvider). ACLAdmin is owned by PayloadsController, controlled by token holders.

**Delegated Steward Roles:**
1. Risk Stewards → Risk Parameters
2. Finance Stewards → Treasury
3. Aave Guardians → Emergency

**Protocol Emergency Guardian:** A separate multisig that executes limited emergency operations for the protocol.

criteria.name: Token Censorship
criteria.about: Examines whether any roles exist that can freeze, blacklist, seize, or otherwise censor token balances or transfers.
criteria.notes: No Guardian or blacklist capabilities exist in the AAVE token contract.

aave.name: Metric 2: Value Accrual
aave.about: This metric evaluates whether the system's operation produces observable, onchain value flows (or token-scarcity effects) that accrue value to tokenholders under rule-based constraints that do not rely on manual transfers, trusted executors, or other unenforced expectations.
aave.summary: Protocol fees flow to governance-controlled treasury. Holders can stake as stkAAVE in Safety Module for yield. Treasury composed of reserve factor from borrower interest + liquidation fees + flashloan premiums. Brand controlled by Quantum Swan OU.

criteria.name: Accrual Active
criteria.about: Assesses whether value flows to tokenholders are currently active rather than merely theoretical or proposed.
criteria.notes: Alongside the protocol fees going to the AAVE token-holder controlled treasury as an important source of value accrual, holders can stake their AAVE tokens as stkAAVE in Aave's Safety module, getting additional AAVE tokens as yield from the treasury for bearing the risk of slashing in case of protocol insolvency. Caveat: this Safety Module is in the transitional phase of being sunset in favour of aToken staking as part of the Umbrella release for automated bad debt coverage, which is live already.

criteria.name: Treasury Ownership
criteria.about: Determines whether protocol treasury assets are programmatically controlled by tokenholder governance.
criteria.notes: AAVE holders control and direct the usage of treasury for protocol growth. Treasury is composed of fees as reserve factor from accrued interests from borrowers + liquidation fees + flashloan premiums

urls.name: ReserveLogic onchain - mintToTreasury() in Pool's implementation contract

criteria.name: Accrual Mechanism Control
criteria.about: Evaluates whether tokenholders can modify parameters governing value capture, such as fees or revenue routing.
criteria.notes: AAVE holders (governance) ultimately control the key levers that determine fee capture and treasury flow: listing/config changes, Reserve Factor (portion of interest skimmed to treasury), liquidation protocol fees, etc., via ACL-gated admin roles. Emergency actions are typically delegated (Guardian / emergency admin), but economic controls are governance-owned, as ACLManager is controlled by AAVE holders. ACLManager's key functions to add/remove pools, admins, riskAdmins etc are controlled by Aave governance: This method can only be called by the Role Admin, specified by Aave Governance, responsible for managing the POOL_ADMIN role.

criteria.name: Offchain Value Accrual
criteria.about: Are there additional offchain value accrual flows that benefit tokenholders?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not verified additional offchain value accrual flows to the AAVE token

aave.name: Metric 3: Verifiability
aave.about: This metric measures whether a token's economically material code and deployments are independently verifiable from primary evidence without relying on insider assurances.
aave.summary: AAVE token proxy and implementation are verified on Etherscan. Aave V3 protocol contracts are open source and verified.

criteria.name: Token Contract Source Verification
criteria.about: Determines whether the token contract's source code is publicly available and verifiably matches the deployed bytecode.
criteria.notes: The AAVE token contract (proxy and implementation) source code is publicly available and verified on Etherscan.

criteria.name: Protocol Component Source Verification
criteria.about: Determines whether core protocol contracts are publicly accessible and verifiable against their onchain deployments.
criteria.notes: Aave V3 protocol contracts are open source on GitHub and verified on Etherscan, including Pool and PoolAddressProvider.

aave.name: Metric 4: Token Distribution
aave.about: This metric evaluates whether ownership and therefore effective voting power in governance is meaningfully distributed.
aave.summary: Aragon has not verified if any 3rd party controls a majority share of the voting power of AAVE or derivatives.

criteria.name: Ownership Concentration
criteria.about: Measures whether a single actor or coordinated group controls a majority of the voting supply.
criteria.notes: Aragon has not yet verified if any 3rd party controls a majority share of the voting power of AAVE or derivatives.

criteria.name: Supply Schedule
criteria.about: Are there known, future events (such as vesting cliffs) that will materially affect the concentration of tokens?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not yet verified the supply schedule criteria for the AAVE token

aave.name: Offchain Dependencies
aave.about: Onchain ownership is only one half the story, in many cases. Distribution controls coordination. Even with immutable contracts, the ability to shift users to a fork or new deployment can break the link between existing tokenholders and future activity.
aave.summary: US AAVE trademark is held by Quantum Swan OU (Estonia). Primary interface terms identify Aave Interfaces Ltd as the contracting party.

criteria.name: Brand
criteria.about: Are core trademarks and brand assets owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: A US AAVE trademark filing lists Quantum Swan OU (Estonia) as the applicant/owner.

criteria.name: Distribution
criteria.about: Are primary domains and distribution assets owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: The primary interface terms identify Aave Interfaces Ltd as the contracting party.

criteria.name: Licensing
criteria.about: Is core protocol software/IP (and any associated licensing rights, where applicable) owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not yet verified all the licensing criteria associated with the AAVE token or the corresponding protocol and assets

aero.name: Metric 1: Onchain Control
aero.about: This metric evaluates whether economically material outcomes are mediated through tokenholder governance, or whether admins, multisigs, security councils, or other privileged roles retain onchain powers that can change the rules or selectively restrict use and exit.
aero.summary: veAERO holders control emissions through epoch-based gauge voting. Core contracts are immutable. An EmergencyCouncil exists for crisis handling. Fee parameters are currently controlled by a Gnosis Safe multisig.

criteria.name: On-chain Governance Workflow
criteria.about: Evaluates whether an onchain process exists that grants tokenholders ultimate authority over protocol decisions.
criteria.notes:
AERO holders lock AERO in VotingEscrow to receive veAERO represented as veNFTs. veAERO holders vote each epoch on gauge weights via the Voter contract. Based on the final vote distribution, the Minter mints weekly AERO emissions, which the Voter distributes to gauges proportionally to votes received.

**EmergencyCouncil:** Exists to handle contingencies. It can be invoked to kill or revive gauges, update pool name and symbol metadata, and rotate the EmergencyCouncil itself.

criteria.name: Role Accountability
criteria.about: Determines whether all privileged or value-impacting roles are governed, revocable, and accountable to tokenholders.
criteria.notes:
veAERO holders indirectly control AERO emissions through epoch-based gauge voting executed by the Voter and Minter.

**EmergencyCouncil:** Exists but is not elected by veAERO holders. It holds limited emergency powers, including killing or reviving gauges and managing pool metadata. This role exists explicitly for crisis handling and sits outside direct tokenholder election.

criteria.name: Protocol Upgrade Authority
criteria.about: Determines whether core protocol logic can be upgraded and whether such upgrades are controlled by tokenholders.
criteria.notes: Core Aerodrome protocol contracts are non-upgradeable and do not use proxy patterns.

criteria.name: Token Upgrade Authority
criteria.about: Assesses whether token behavior can be modified and, if so, whether such changes are controlled by tokenholder governance.
criteria.notes: The AERO token contract is immutable and does not use a proxy pattern. The Minter contract, which is authorized to mint AERO, is also non-upgradeable.

criteria.name: Supply Control
criteria.about: Evaluates whether token supply changes are programmatic or subject exclusively to tokenholder-approved governance processes.
criteria.notes:
AERO minting is fully programmatic and epoch-based (1 epoch = 1 week), enforced by the non-upgradeable Minter contract.

**Emission Rate:** Can be increased/decreased by governance but only in fixed, small, weekly increments of +/-0.01%.

**Growth Emissions:** The protocol separately mints growth emissions for veAERO holders using the formula: weeklyEmissions * (1 - veAERO.totalSupply / AERO.totalSupply)^2 * 0.5. This creates a counter-cyclical incentive where veAERO rewards decrease as more AERO is locked and increase when less AERO is locked.

**Team Emission Rate:** Currently set to 0% of total weekly emissions.

criteria.name: Privileged Access Gating
criteria.about: Assesses whether any bounded actor set can block or selectively restrict economically meaningful protocol actions or exit paths, versus access that is permissionless and symmetric for similarly situated users.
criteria.notes:
**Non-SlipStream:** Fees are set on the PoolFactory which can be changed by the feeManager (set to Gnosis Safe).

**SlipStream:** For CLPoolFactory, fees are set inside the SwapFeeModule which allows feeManager to change fees (currently set to Gnosis Safe).

urls.name: SwapFeeModule: setCustomFee is allowed by CLFactory.swapFeeManager = GnosisSafe

criteria.name: Token Censorship
criteria.about: Examines whether any roles exist that can freeze, blacklist, seize, or otherwise censor token balances or transfers.
criteria.notes:
The AERO token has no blacklist, pause, or seizure mechanisms.

**Team Rate:** The team rate (share of weekly emissions allocated to the team) can be modified by a Gnosis Safe controlled by the Aerodrome team.

**Emission Rate:** Changes to the weekly emission rate (+/-0.01% or unchanged) are controlled by Governor (a multisig), soon to be handed over to governance contracts controlled by veAERO holders.

urls.name: Emission Rate Change By Governor set to different Gnosis Safe

aero.name: Metric 2: Value Accrual
aero.about: This metric evaluates whether the system's operation produces observable, onchain value flows (or token-scarcity effects) that accrue value to tokenholders under rule-based constraints that do not rely on manual transfers, trusted executors, or other unenforced expectations.
aero.summary: veAERO holders receive growth emissions and trading fees from staked LP positions. There is no protocol treasury - all trading fees are distributed. Offchain brand controlled by Aerodrome Foundation.

criteria.name: Accrual Active
criteria.about: Assesses whether value flows to tokenholders are currently active rather than merely theoretical or proposed.
criteria.notes:
**Growth Emissions:** veAERO holders receive rewards from growth emissions (see Supply section). These are transferred to RewardDistributor and veAERO holders can claim in proportion to their ve balance.

**Trading Fees:** For both normal and slipstream (CL) pools, the swap fees meant for LPs who have staked their LP tokens in gauges go to veAERO holders.

urls.name: Gauge Deposit Logic (see earned function as well)
Non-Slipstream: Voter calling Gauge to claim fees
Non-Slipstream: Swap Fee Claimed by Gauge on PoolFees

criteria.name: Treasury Ownership
criteria.about: Determines whether protocol treasury assets are programmatically controlled by tokenholder governance.
criteria.notes: There is no protocol treasury. All trading fees from swapping pools are distributed to veAERO holders and LPs.

criteria.name: Accrual Mechanism Control
criteria.about: Evaluates whether tokenholders can modify parameters governing value capture, such as fees or revenue routing.
criteria.notes:
veAERO holders control:

1. The AERO rewards they receive by locking AERO tokens in VotingEscrow

2. The AERO emissions going into gauges by voting for them in Voter

criteria.name: Offchain Value Accrual
criteria.about: Are there additional offchain value accrual flows that benefit tokenholders?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not verified additional offchain value accrual flows to the AERO token

aero.name: Metric 3: Verifiability
aero.about: This metric measures whether a token's economically material code and deployments are independently verifiable from primary evidence without relying on insider assurances.
aero.summary: AERO token source is publicly available on GitHub and verified on Basescan. Aerodrome protocol contracts are open source and verified.

criteria.name: Token Contract Source Verification
criteria.about: Determines whether the token contract's source code is publicly available and verifiably matches the deployed bytecode.
criteria.notes: The AERO token contract source code (Aero.sol) is publicly available on GitHub and verified on Basescan.

criteria.name: Protocol Component Source Verification
criteria.about: Determines whether core protocol contracts are publicly accessible and verifiable against their onchain deployments.
criteria.notes: Aerodrome protocol contracts (including Slipstream) are open source on GitHub and verified on Basescan.

aero.name: Metric 4: Token Distribution
aero.about: This metric evaluates whether ownership and therefore effective voting power in governance is meaningfully distributed.
aero.summary: Distribution of AERO and veAERO voting power outside of the core team has not been independently verified.

criteria.name: Ownership Concentration
criteria.about: Measures whether a single actor or coordinated group controls a majority of the voting supply.
criteria.notes: Distribution of AERO and veAERO voting power outside of the core team has not been independently verified.

criteria.name: Supply Schedule
criteria.about: Are there known, future events (such as vesting cliffs) that will materially affect the concentration of tokens?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not yet verified the supply schedule criteria for the AERO token

aero.name: Offchain Dependencies
aero.about: Onchain ownership is only one half the story, in many cases. Distribution controls coordination. Even with immutable contracts, the ability to shift users to a fork or new deployment can break the link between existing tokenholders and future activity.
aero.summary: US AERODROME trademark is held by Perpetual Cyclist Services LLC (Delaware). Primary interface terms identify the Aerodrome Foundation as the contracting party.

criteria.name: Brand
criteria.about: Are core trademarks and brand assets owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: A US AERODROME trademark filing lists Perpetual Cyclist Services LLC (Delaware) as the applicant/owner.

criteria.name: Distribution
criteria.about: Are primary domains and distribution assets owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: The primary interface terms identify the Aerodrome Foundation as the contracting party.

criteria.name: Licensing
criteria.about: Is core protocol software/IP (and any associated licensing rights, where applicable) owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not yet verified all the licensing criteria associated with the AERO token or the corresponding protocol and assets

crv.name: Metric 1: Onchain Control
crv.about: This metric evaluates whether economically material outcomes are mediated through tokenholder governance, or whether admins, multisigs, security councils, or other privileged roles retain onchain powers that can change the rules or selectively restrict use and exit.
crv.summary: veCRV holders control all protocol operations through Aragon v1's Voting Contract and Agent. The CRV token is immutable with programmatic inflation and no censorship capabilities. Core protocol and pool contracts are immutable.

criteria.name: On-chain Governance Workflow
criteria.about: Evaluates whether an onchain process exists that grants tokenholders ultimate authority over protocol decisions.
criteria.notes: Governance is enforced through Aragon v1's Voting Contract, which authorizes execution via the Agent contract. The Agent contract is set as the owner for all protocol-gated functions, ensuring veCRV holders control all operations.

urls.name: CRV Token: Admin is set to Agent

criteria.name: Role Accountability
criteria.about: Determines whether all privileged or value-impacting roles are governed, revocable, and accountable to tokenholders.
criteria.notes:
Protocol roles are controlled by the Agent.

**Gauge Addition:** Only the Agent can add new gauges via add_gauge on GaugeController.

**Fee Parameters:** Pool admin fees are set at deployment and can be modified by Agent (through veCRV holders voting) - see accrual section for more info.

**Pool Factory Ownership:** New pools are deployed by Factory contracts controlled by OwnerProxy contract. This contract has two types of admin (Agent and GnosisSafe). Agent is responsible for adding new pools, giving veCRV holders control over protocol expansion.

urls.name: GaugeController: admin is set to Agent
Curve Pool Factory: admin is set to OwnerProxy

criteria.name: Protocol Upgrade Authority
criteria.about: Determines whether core protocol logic can be upgraded and whether such upgrades are controlled by tokenholders.
criteria.notes:
Core protocol and pool contracts are immutable.

**Agent Contract:** Can be upgraded by calling setApp(Agent, ...) on the Kernel contract, which is only allowed by the Agent itself. Only veCRV holders can upgrade the Agent contract through governance voting.

**Voting Contract:** Can be upgraded by calling setApp(Voting, ...) on the Kernel contract, which is only allowed by the Agent itself. Only veCRV holders can upgrade the Voting contract through governance voting.

criteria.name: Token Upgrade Authority
criteria.about: Assesses whether token behavior can be modified and, if so, whether such changes are controlled by tokenholder governance.
criteria.notes: The CRV token contract is immutable with no proxy patterns or upgrade mechanisms.

criteria.name: Supply Control
criteria.about: Evaluates whether token supply changes are programmatic or subject exclusively to tokenholder-approved governance processes.
criteria.notes: Curve's token inflation is released in yearly epochs: each year allows a fixed maximum amount to be minted linearly over time, and at the end of the year the minting rate is reduced by a factor of 2^1/4. Any unminted supply from a year is permanently lost. Mint can only occur by Minter which decides how much to mint for an user depending on the veCRV balance and provided LP tokens in a gauge.

criteria.name: Privileged Access Gating
criteria.about: Assesses whether any bounded actor set can block or selectively restrict economically meaningful protocol actions or exit paths, versus access that is permissionless and symmetric for similarly situated users.
criteria.notes:
Core protocol functions are either permissionless or gated by Agent contract (hence veCRV holders). For gate control related to fees/revenues, see accrual section.

**Add/Kill Gauge:** To add a new gauge in GaugeController, veCRV holders must vote in majority. The admin on GaugeController is set to the Aragon Agent Contract, which sits as the final step in the governance process. Governance starts with the Aragon Voting contract that uses veCRV token for voting. veCRV holders can also kill a gauge, permanently setting its rewards to 0.

criteria.name: Token Censorship
criteria.about: Examines whether any roles exist that can freeze, blacklist, seize, or otherwise censor token balances or transfers.
criteria.notes: The CRV token has no transfer restrictions, blacklist functionality, or pausable transfers. There's Admin set (Agent) on the CRV token, but it can only update token's name and symbol.

crv.name: Metric 2: Value Accrual
crv.about: This metric evaluates whether the system's operation produces observable, onchain value flows (or token-scarcity effects) that accrue value to tokenholders under rule-based constraints that do not rely on manual transfers, trusted executors, or other unenforced expectations.
crv.summary: veCRV holders receive 50% of all trading fees distributed as crvUSD rewards. Value flows are programmatic through the gauge system. Offchain structure shows Swiss Stake AG controls the interface and trademark.

criteria.name: Accrual Active
criteria.about: Assesses whether value flows to tokenholders are currently active rather than merely theoretical or proposed.
criteria.notes:
**CRV Emissions Rewards:** Liquidity Providers deposit LP tokens into the Gauge Contract. Once the gauge receives CRV emissions, LPs can claim their proportional rewards based on their deposited LP token amount.

**2.5x Boost in CRV Emissions:** LPs can boost rewards up to 2.5x by locking CRV for veCRV. The user reward is based on a working balance and 2.5x reward is enforced by TOKENLESS_PRODUCTION which is set to 40 (i.e., 40 * 2.5 = 100%).

**Pool Rewards in crvUSD:** Pools have two fees: fee (total swap fee) and admin_fee (percentage of fee taken for admin) which is applied when the swap occurs. StableSwapProxy calls withdraw_admin_fees on pools to collect admin portion of fees. Every coin inside StableSwapProxy has a burner contract attached. Later, anyone can call burn which invokes the coin's attached burner contract to transfer fees from StableSwapProxy. One such burner is FeeCollector, where fees ultimately accumulate. FeeCollector uses CowSwapBurner to convert all tokens to crvUSD, and the crvUSD is sent to FeeDistributor where veCRV holders can claim their rewards.

**Borrow Rewards in crvUSD:** Borrowing Interest (paid in crvUSD) from controllers are sent to FeeSplitter. FeeCollector receives proportional crvUSD from FeeSplitter and sends to FeeDistributor for veCRV holders.

urls.name: working_balance uses user's LP tokens and veCRV balance to decide reward

criteria.name: Treasury Ownership
criteria.about: Determines whether protocol treasury assets are programmatically controlled by tokenholder governance.
criteria.notes: 50% of all trading fees are distributed to veCRV holders through crvUSD rewards, while the remaining 50% goes to the respective liquidity providers of the pools. Only veCRV holders can change this behaviour, hence Curve has no separate treasury. All revenue to the people.

criteria.name: Accrual Mechanism Control
criteria.about: Evaluates whether tokenholders can modify parameters governing value capture, such as fees or revenue routing.
criteria.notes:
Gauge weights are determined programmatically by veCRV votes, not discretionary decisions.

**Update Pool Fees:** Pool fee changes are executed via commit_new_fee, which can only be called by the pool owner (StableSwapProxy) which in turn is restricted to parameter_admin (Agent contract).

**Attaching a Burner Contract:** set_burner on StableSwapProxy is gated by ownership_admin (Agent contract).

**Burn:** The burn function invokes each coin's attached burner contract. Can be disabled by either the Agent contract or the emergency Safe multisig.

criteria.name: Offchain Value Accrual
criteria.about: Are there additional offchain value accrual flows that benefit tokenholders?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not verified additional offchain value accrual flows to the CRV token

crv.name: Metric 3: Verifiability
crv.about: This metric measures whether a token's economically material code and deployments are independently verifiable from primary evidence without relying on insider assurances.
crv.summary: CRV token source (Vyper) is publicly available on GitHub and verified on Etherscan. Curve DAO contracts are open source and verified.

criteria.name: Token Contract Source Verification
criteria.about: Determines whether the token contract's source code is publicly available and verifiably matches the deployed bytecode.
criteria.notes: The CRV token contract source code (ERC20CRV.vy) is publicly available on GitHub and verified on Etherscan.

criteria.name: Protocol Component Source Verification
criteria.about: Determines whether core protocol contracts are publicly accessible and verifiable against their onchain deployments.
criteria.notes: Curve DAO protocol contracts are open source on GitHub and verified on Etherscan, including GaugeController and Agent.

crv.name: Metric 4: Token Distribution
crv.about: This metric evaluates whether ownership and therefore effective voting power in governance is meaningfully distributed.
crv.summary: Aragon has not verified if the majority of veCRV voting power lies with a single party.

criteria.name: Ownership Concentration
criteria.about: Measures whether a single actor or coordinated group controls a majority of the voting supply.
criteria.notes: Aragon has not yet verified if the majority of veCRV voting power lies with a single party

criteria.name: Supply Schedule
criteria.about: Are there known, future events (such as vesting cliffs) that will materially affect the concentration of tokens?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not yet verified the supply schedule criteria for the CRV token

crv.name: Offchain Dependencies
crv.about: Onchain ownership is only one half the story, in many cases. Distribution controls coordination. Even with immutable contracts, the ability to shift users to a fork or new deployment can break the link between existing tokenholders and future activity.
crv.summary: Swiss CRV trademark is held by Swiss Stake AG. Curve interface terms identify Swiss Stake AG (Zug, Switzerland) as the contracting party.

criteria.name: Brand
criteria.about: Are core trademarks and brand assets owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: The Swiss CRV trademark registration lists Swiss Stake AG as the owner.

criteria.name: Distribution
criteria.about: Are primary domains and distribution assets owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: The Curve interface terms identify Swiss Stake AG (Zug, Switzerland) as the contracting party.

criteria.name: Licensing
criteria.about: Is core protocol software/IP (and any associated licensing rights, where applicable) owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not yet verified all the licensing criteria associated with the CRV token or the corresponding protocol and assets

ldo.name: Metric 1: Onchain Control
ldo.about: This metric evaluates whether economically material outcomes are mediated through tokenholder governance, or whether admins, multisigs, security councils, or other privileged roles retain onchain powers that can change the rules or selectively restrict use and exit.
ldo.summary: LDO holders exercise ultimate control through a multi-step governance flow with stETH holder veto protection via Dual Governance. All critical roles flow through governance-controlled contracts. The token has unbounded supply controlled by governance, with token behavior modifiable through controller upgrades.

criteria.name: On-chain Governance Workflow
criteria.about: Evaluates whether an onchain process exists that grants tokenholders ultimate authority over protocol decisions.
criteria.notes:
**Governance 1A:** Voting (LDO holders) → DualGovernance (stETH challenge window) → EmergencyProtectedTimeLock (time delay) → Executor → Agent → Protocol Contracts. LDO holders have ultimate control, constrained by stETH right to exit when disagreeing. This flow is used for protocol-related contracts.

**Governance 1B:** Voting (LDO holders) → Protocol Contracts. This flow is used for DAO-related contracts.

**Governance 2 (Easy Track):** An optimistic governance system where certain operations can be vetoed by LDO holders but are assumed to pass. Used for granting, treasury operations, and staking module management. Motions pass automatically unless ≥0.5% LDO objects within 72 hours. Permissionless execution post-timelock if unopposed; rejected motions escalate to full Aragon vote.

criteria.name: Role Accountability
criteria.about: Determines whether all privileged or value-impacting roles are governed, revocable, and accountable to tokenholders.
criteria.notes:
All critical roles flow through governance-controlled contracts, ensuring LDO holders maintain ultimate control over the protocol.

**Voting:** Controlled by LDO holders.

**Agent:** EXECUTE_ROLE is given to Executor. Executor is owned by EmergencyProtectedTimeLock, which is controlled by DualGovernance, which is controlled by Voting contract.

**TokenManager:** MINT_ROLE is given to Voting contract. BURN_ROLE is given to no one, but its permission manager is Voting contract.

**StakingRouter:** STAKING_MODULE_MANAGE_ROLE is given to Agent contract. Since Agent is only callable by Governance 1, all operations are controlled by LDO holders.

criteria.name: Protocol Upgrade Authority
criteria.about: Determines whether core protocol logic can be upgraded and whether such upgrades are controlled by tokenholders.
criteria.notes:
The protocol contracts can be upgraded by the Agent contract (hence, by LDO holders).

**StakingRouter:** proxy_getAdmin is set to Agent.

**Agent:** Uses Aragon v1 Proxy. Upgrading requires calling setApp(Agent, ...) on the Kernel, which requires APP_MANAGER_ROLE (currently given to Agent itself).

**Non-upgradeable:** DualGovernance, Executor, EmergencyProtectedTimeLock.

criteria.name: Token Upgrade Authority
criteria.about: Assesses whether token behavior can be modified and, if so, whether such changes are controlled by tokenholder governance.
criteria.notes:
The LDO token contract is **immutable** with no proxy pattern. However, it has a controller address (TokenManager) that can call privileged functions (generateTokens, destroyTokens, enableTransfers, claimTokens).

The token's doTransfer function includes a hook that calls the controller contract, which is upgradeable. Since TokenManager is upgradeable via Aragon proxy, the token's behavior can be modified through controller upgrades, making LDO Token **partially upgradeable** in practice.

Upgrading TokenManager requires calling setApp(tokenManager, ...) on the Kernel, protected by APP_MANAGER_ROLE, which is assigned to the Agent contract.

criteria.name: Supply Control
criteria.about: Evaluates whether token supply changes are programmatic or subject exclusively to tokenholder-approved governance processes.
criteria.notes: The LDO token's controller (TokenManager) can mint unlimited tokens. However, minting requires MINT_ROLE on TokenManager, which is held by the Voting contract. This enforces the minting path: Voting (LDO holders) to TokenManager to Token.generateTokens(). No supply cap exists, but all mints require tokenholder approval.

criteria.name: Privileged Access Gating
criteria.about: Assesses whether any bounded actor set can block or selectively restrict economically meaningful protocol actions or exit paths, versus access that is permissionless and symmetric for similarly situated users.
criteria.notes:
User funds deposited into Lido Protocol are accumulated in the buffer and can only be deposited into a staking module by DepositSecurityModule, which is controlled by **Guardians** (node operators + LDO dev team), not LDO holders directly.

While deposits are operationally executed by Guardians, this does not constitute privileged protocol control independent of LDO holders:

1. Guardians are **fully accountable** to LDO holders—they can be rotated, replaced, or their mandate changed through on-chain voting.

2. Guardians **do not control** protocol parameters or economic risk. They cannot change staking ratios, fee splits, module shares, or risk parameters.

criteria.name: Token Censorship
criteria.about: Examines whether any roles exist that can freeze, blacklist, seize, or otherwise censor token balances or transfers.
criteria.notes: Controller can burn tokens from any address and enable/disable transfers. Currently, BURN_ROLE on the TokenManager is given to no one, but permission manager is Voting contract. To enable burning, proposal must go through Governance 1B to call setPermission on ACL.

ldo.name: Metric 2: Value Accrual
ldo.about: This metric evaluates whether the system's operation produces observable, onchain value flows (or token-scarcity effects) that accrue value to tokenholders under rule-based constraints that do not rely on manual transfers, trusted executors, or other unenforced expectations.
ldo.summary: LDO holders currently have no direct value accrual mechanism from protocol revenue. Governance is exploring buyback mechanisms. The treasury is controlled by LDO holders, and offchain IP is held by DAO-controlled BORG foundations.

criteria.name: Accrual Active
criteria.about: Assesses whether value flows to tokenholders are currently active rather than merely theoretical or proposed.
criteria.notes: LDO token holders currently have no direct value accrual mechanism from protocol revenue. However, governance is exploring buyback mechanisms to return value to token holders, with proposals under consideration for liquid buyback execution using protocol treasury funds.

criteria.name: Treasury Ownership
criteria.about: Determines whether protocol treasury assets are programmatically controlled by tokenholder governance.
criteria.notes: The Lido DAO Treasury is the Agent contract itself, controlled by LDO holders. Decisions on Treasury Management excluded from the Dual Governance scope and can't be challenged by stETH holders. The Treasury Management Committee is responsible for maintaining and executing policies related to treasury management in accordance with the approved principles. The committee proposes and enacts strategies and decisions via Governance 2. LDO holders, via Governance 1A, control treasury revenue by approving staking modules and setting and updating each module's treasury fee in the StakingRouter. This fee determines the portion of staking rewards routed to the Lido treasury.

criteria.name: Accrual Mechanism Control
criteria.about: Evaluates whether tokenholders can modify parameters governing value capture, such as fees or revenue routing.
criteria.notes: To add a new staking module or update it with new fees, full governance flow required, hence controlled by LDO holders.

criteria.name: Offchain Value Accrual
criteria.about: Are there additional offchain value accrual flows that benefit tokenholders?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not verified additional offchain value accrual flows to the LDO token

ldo.name: Metric 3: Verifiability
ldo.about: This metric measures whether a token's economically material code and deployments are independently verifiable from primary evidence without relying on insider assurances.
ldo.summary: LDO token source is publicly available and verified on Etherscan. Lido core protocol contracts are open source and verified.

criteria.name: Token Contract Source Verification
criteria.about: Determines whether the token contract's source code is publicly available and verifiably matches the deployed bytecode.
criteria.notes: The LDO token contract source code is publicly available on GitHub (MiniMeToken) and verified on Etherscan.

criteria.name: Protocol Component Source Verification
criteria.about: Determines whether core protocol contracts are publicly accessible and verifiable against their onchain deployments.
criteria.notes: Lido core protocol contracts are open source on GitHub and verified on Etherscan, including StakingRouter and Agent contracts.

ldo.name: Metric 4: Token Distribution
ldo.about: This metric evaluates whether ownership and therefore effective voting power in governance is meaningfully distributed.
ldo.summary: Aragon has not yet verified the distribution of LDO holders outside of the core team.

criteria.name: Ownership Concentration
criteria.about: Measures whether a single actor or coordinated group controls a majority of the voting supply.
criteria.notes: Aragon has not yet verified the distribution of LDO holders outside of the core team is greater than 50%

criteria.name: Supply Schedule
criteria.about: Are there known, future events (such as vesting cliffs) that will materially affect the concentration of tokens?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not yet verified the supply schedule criteria for the LDO token

ldo.name: Offchain Dependencies
ldo.about: Onchain ownership is only one half the story, in many cases. Distribution controls coordination. Even with immutable contracts, the ability to shift users to a fork or new deployment can break the link between existing tokenholders and future activity.
ldo.summary: European trademark registrations for LIDO list Lido Labs Foundation as the owner. Lido Labs, Ecosystem, and Alliance BORG Foundations are DAO-controlled entities managing offchain IP and distribution.

criteria.name: Brand
criteria.about: Are core trademarks and brand assets owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: European trademark registrations for LIDO list Lido Labs Foundation as the owner.

criteria.name: Distribution
criteria.about: Are primary domains and distribution assets owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: Lido Labs BORG Foundation, Lido Ecosystem BORG Foundation, Lido Alliance BORG Foundation is a memberless DAO-adjacent foundation companies under which the Lido DAO has defined governance controls (including appointing/removing directors and overseeing BORG structures).

criteria.name: Licensing
criteria.about: Is core protocol software/IP (and any associated licensing rights, where applicable) owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: Lido Labs BORG Foundation, Lido Ecosystem BORG Foundation, Lido Alliance BORG Foundation is a memberless DAO-adjacent foundation companies under which the Lido DAO has defined governance controls (including appointing/removing directors and overseeing BORG structures).

uni.name: Metric 1: Onchain Control
uni.about: This metric evaluates whether economically material outcomes are mediated through tokenholder governance, or whether admins, multisigs, security councils, or other privileged roles retain onchain powers that can change the rules or selectively restrict use and exit.
uni.summary: UNI holders maintain ultimate control through GovernorBravoDelegator and Timelock. The token is immutable with a hardcoded 2% annual inflation cap. All core contracts (V2, V3, V4) are non-upgradeable with no pause/freeze functions.

criteria.name: On-chain Governance Workflow
criteria.about: Evaluates whether an onchain process exists that grants tokenholders ultimate authority over protocol decisions.
criteria.notes: UNI holders vote onchain via GovernorBravoDelegator, with execution through Timelock after a time delay.

criteria.name: Role Accountability
criteria.about: Determines whether all privileged or value-impacting roles are governed, revocable, and accountable to tokenholders.
criteria.notes:
All critical roles flow through governance-controlled contracts, ensuring UNI holders maintain ultimate control.

**V2Factory:** feeToSetter is Timelock. Only feeToSetter can call setFeeTo() to change fee destination.

**V3Factory:** Owner is V3FeeAdapter, whose feeSetter is Timelock. Only Timelock can change V3 protocol fees.

**V4PoolManager:** Owner is Timelock. Only owner can call setProtocolFeeController().

**UNI Token:** Minter is Timelock. Since Timelock is controlled by GovernorBravoDelegator, all operations are controlled by UNI holders.

criteria.name: Protocol Upgrade Authority
criteria.about: Determines whether core protocol logic can be upgraded and whether such upgrades are controlled by tokenholders.
criteria.notes:
All Uniswap Pair contracts and Timelock are non-upgradeable, whereas GovernorBravoDelegator is upgradeable.

**UniswapV2Pair.sol:** Uses Create2 deployment.

**UniswapV3Pool.sol:** Uses NoDelegateCall protection.

**PoolManager.sol (V4):** Uses Singleton design.

**GovernorBravoDelegator.sol:** Admin (who can upgrade) is set to Timelock contract which again requires governance flow to go through.

criteria.name: Token Upgrade Authority
criteria.about: Assesses whether token behavior can be modified and, if so, whether such changes are controlled by tokenholder governance.
criteria.notes: Token contract is immutable with no proxy patterns, no delegatecall, no EIP-1967/UUPS patterns.

criteria.name: Supply Control
criteria.about: Evaluates whether token supply changes are programmatic or subject exclusively to tokenholder-approved governance processes.
criteria.notes: Mint can be called once per year which mints 2% of total supply. Note that mintCap is constant and can not be changed. Minter is set to Timelock governed by token holders.

criteria.name: Privileged Access Gating
criteria.about: Assesses whether any bounded actor set can block or selectively restrict economically meaningful protocol actions or exit paths, versus access that is permissionless and symmetric for similarly situated users.
criteria.notes: No pause/freeze functions in V2 Pair, V3 Pool, or V4 PoolManager core contracts. No admin backdoors to steal funds. No emergency withdrawal or sweep functions.

criteria.name: Token Censorship
criteria.about: Examines whether any roles exist that can freeze, blacklist, seize, or otherwise censor token balances or transfers.
criteria.notes: No blacklist, whitelist, or pause functions in UNI token contract. Transfers cannot be censored. Standard ERC20 with no admin controls over transfers.

uni.name: Metric 2: Value Accrual
uni.about: This metric evaluates whether the system's operation produces observable, onchain value flows (or token-scarcity effects) that accrue value to tokenholders under rule-based constraints that do not rely on manual transfers, trusted executors, or other unenforced expectations.
uni.summary: Protocol fees flow to governance-controlled destinations through TokenJar and FirePit burn mechanism. Treasury (~$1.4B) is entirely controlled by token holders. Brand and distribution controlled by Uniswap Labs, with DUNI structure for potential transfer.

criteria.name: Accrual Active
criteria.about: Assesses whether value flows to tokenholders are currently active rather than merely theoretical or proposed.
criteria.notes:
Protocol fees across all Uniswap versions (V2, V3, V4) flow to governance-controlled destinations (TokenJar). Value accrual is via burn mechanism - anyone can burn 4,000 UNI to claim accumulated protocol fees from TokenJar via FirePit.

**V2:** Fees go to FeeTo address which is set to TokenJar.

**V3:** V3FeeAdapter collects protocol fees by calling collectProtocol and sends them to TokenJar. The 4,000 UNI threshold can be changed by governance via Timelock in FirePit.

**V4:** Fees have not been activated yet, but Timelock (hence UNI holders) will set ProtocolFeeController address to V4FeeAdapter on the PoolManager which will call collectProtocolFees(), with a recipient as TokenJar.

criteria.name: Treasury Ownership
criteria.about: Determines whether protocol treasury assets are programmatically controlled by tokenholder governance.
criteria.notes: The treasury (~$1.4B) at the time of writing, is entirely controlled by token holders. UNI tokens were initially minted to EOA, which transferred portions to TreasuryVester (which has recipient: Timelock). Vester's claim() (callable by anyone) followed a schedule to gradually vest UNI to Timelock without rapid dilution. Funds held in Timelock require UNI governance proposals to execute transfers, ensuring tokenholder control.

criteria.name: Accrual Mechanism Control
criteria.about: Evaluates whether tokenholders can modify parameters governing value capture, such as fees or revenue routing.
criteria.notes:
Token holders control the fee switch and burn threshold (in FirePit) through governance proposals. UNI holders control fee routing across all versions through Timelock-governed ownership.

**V2:** feeToSetter is set to Timelock on UniswapV2Factory. Only feeToSetter can call setFeeTo to change the fee destination. Protocol fees can only be enabled or disabled, not adjusted.

**V3:** Owner of UniswapV3Factory is V3FeeAdapter, whose owner is Timelock. Only factory owner can call setOwner to change fee adapter control. Protocol fee percentage can be changed by the pool owner via setFeeProtocol.

**V4:** Owner of V4PoolManager is set to Timelock. Only owner can call setProtocolFeeController to change the fee controller. Protocol fees can be modified by the PoolManager owner through setProtocolFee.

criteria.name: Offchain Value Accrual
criteria.about: Are there additional offchain value accrual flows that benefit tokenholders?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not verified additional offchain value accrual flows to the UNI token

uni.name: Metric 3: Verifiability
uni.about: This metric measures whether a token's economically material code and deployments are independently verifiable from primary evidence without relying on insider assurances.
uni.summary: UNI token source is publicly available on GitHub and verified on Etherscan. Uniswap V2, V3, and V4 protocol contracts are open source and verified.

criteria.name: Token Contract Source Verification
criteria.about: Determines whether the token contract's source code is publicly available and verifiably matches the deployed bytecode.
criteria.notes: The UNI token contract source code (Uni.sol) is publicly available on GitHub and verified on Etherscan.

criteria.name: Protocol Component Source Verification
criteria.about: Determines whether core protocol contracts are publicly accessible and verifiable against their onchain deployments.
criteria.notes: Uniswap V2, V3, and V4 protocol contracts are open source on GitHub and verified on Etherscan.

uni.name: Metric 4: Token Distribution
uni.about: This metric evaluates whether ownership and therefore effective voting power in governance is meaningfully distributed.
uni.summary: Aragon has not verified that 3rd parties do not hold more than 50% of voting power.

criteria.name: Ownership Concentration
criteria.about: Measures whether a single actor or coordinated group controls a majority of the voting supply.
criteria.notes: Aragon has not yet verified that 3rd parties do not hold more than 50% of voting power

criteria.name: Supply Schedule
criteria.about: Are there known, future events (such as vesting cliffs) that will materially affect the concentration of tokens?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not yet verified the supply schedule criteria for the UNI token

uni.name: Offchain Dependencies
uni.about: Onchain ownership is only one half the story, in many cases. Distribution controls coordination. Even with immutable contracts, the ability to shift users to a fork or new deployment can break the link between existing tokenholders and future activity.
uni.summary: Core UNISWAP trademark rights are held by Universal Navigation Inc. (Uniswap Labs). Uniswap Governance recently adopted DUNI (a Wyoming DUNA) as the legal structure representing token holders offchain.

criteria.name: Brand
criteria.about: Are core trademarks and brand assets owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: Core UNISWAP trademark rights are held/enforced by Universal Navigation Inc. d/b/a Uniswap Labs. Note: Uniswap Governance recently adopted DUNI (a Wyoming DUNA) as the legal structure representing token holders offchain, thus brand assets could be licensed or transferred to token holders.

criteria.name: Distribution
criteria.about: Are primary domains and distribution assets owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: The primary interface terms identify Uniswap Labs (Universal Navigation Inc.) as the contracting party. Note: Uniswap Governance recently adopted DUNI (a Wyoming DUNA) as the legal structure representing token holders offchain, thus distribution assets could be licensed or transferred.

criteria.name: Licensing
criteria.about: Is core protocol software/IP (and any associated licensing rights, where applicable) owned or controlled by a tokenholder-controlled legal entity?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not yet verified all the licensing criteria associated with the UNI token or the corresponding protocol and assets
